projectDesc.p: "Your friend whomever you repugn repugns" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.
For clarification, I have added diacritics to letters left unmarked in this edition.

app.lem: صديقك مَن يُعادي مَن تُعاديبطول الدَّهر ما سجع الحمامُ
app.rdg:
Your friend whomever you repugn repugns
So long as pigeons coo;

app.lem: ويُوفي الدَّينَ عنك بغير مَطْلٍولا يمنُن به أبَداً دوامُ
app.rdg:
Pays without delay your debt,
Never guilting you it.

app.lem: فإن صافى صديقك مَن تعاديويفرح حين ترشُقُك السِّهامُ
app.rdg:
Should your friend your foe underwrite,
Enjoying arrows’ flight,

app.lem: فذاك هو العدوُّ بغير شكٍّتجنَّبه فصُحبته حرام
app.rdg:
Then surely he’s the foe, no doubt.
Quit him. His friendship’s out.

app.lem: فإنَّا قد سمعنا بيت شعرٍشبيه الدُّر زينُه النِّظامُ:
app.rdg:
We heard a verse,
Pearly in its framework:

app.lem: "إذا وافى صديقك مَن تُعاديفقد عاداك، وانفَصَل الكلامُ"
app.rdg:
“Once your friend your foe upholds he
Crosses, end of story.”
